title: Steve Clarke still thinking long-term as Scotland bid to arrest slump starting with Euro 2020 qualifier in Russia
text:
As he looks to the Nations League play-offs that represent Scotland’s only chance of competing in the Euro 2020 finals – during which Hampden Park will host four ties – Steve Clarke will not experiment or add friendlies to the Scots’ schedule between now and March. The Nations League contenders have yet to be confirmed, but Scotland will meet Serbia or Norway or either Israel or Bulgaria, depending on the outcome of the tournament’s tortuous elimination process.

In the meantime, Clarke will focus on the tattered remnants of the Scots’ Euro 2020 campaign, beginning with Thursday’s meeting with Russia in the Luzhniki Stadium and the visit of San Marino to Hampden Park next Sunday, followed by Cyprus away and Kazakhstan at home in November.

Clarke was hailed as the people’s choice when he succeeded Alex McLeish in May but he has so far been unable to arrest a deeply dispiriting slump which began with humiliation by the Kazakhs in Astana.

According to HMRC, sales of Scotch reached a record high of £3 billion in the first half of this year. We need not look far for the cause. The Tartan Army’s need of a general anaesthetic is explained by the Group I table, currently led by Belgium, followed by Russia, Kazakhstan and Cyprus.

San Marino, the section makeweights, are bottom but, if one excludes the microstate whose population equals that of Dumfries (33,000), then the Scottish record makes pitiable reading – one scrabbled win away to the Sammarinese and another at home to Cyprus. Clarke’s task, if he is to retain credibility amongst a battered support, is to finish best of the stragglers.
